p: In addition to stigma and medical mistrust, which are well-documented in the literature, future studies must identify the role other psychosocial factors play with iART. The role of structural racism and homophobia, and other forms of structural discrimination—that is, in the form of cultural norms and institutional policies—and their interplay with iART is an important area of potential inquiry [ 49]. Health literacy is yet another issue that influences HIV health outcomes and may carry particular resonance in the context of iART and health equity, given the need to immediately understand and agree with a pharmacological intervention (i.e., ART), as well as the complexity of navigating the health system for patients living with HIV [ 50].
